ieee: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
sparql: SPARQL Protocol and RDF Query Language
nist: National Institute of Standards and Technology
cdc: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
hipaa: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
pneumatic: Containing or Operated by Air or Gas Under Pressure
ultraviolet: Beyond the Violet End of the Spectrum
catalyst: Substance That Increases the Rate of a Chemical Reaction
codata: Committee on Data for Science and Technology
crispr: Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats
hsab: Hard and Soft Acids and Bases
isotope: Atoms with the Same Number of Protons but Different Neutrons
solubility: Ability of a Substance to Dissolve in Another Substance
stoichiometry: Relationships Between the Quantities of Substances in Chemical Reactions
wavelength: Distance Between Successive Peaks of a Wave
zymogram: Gel Electrophoresis Technique for Analyzing Enzymes
algebra: Branch of Mathematics Dealing with Symbols and the Rules for Manipulating Those Symbols
area: Measure of the Amount of Space Enclosed by a Figure
cpctc: Corresponding Parts of Congruent Triangles are Congruent
factorial: Product of All Positive Integers Up to a Given Number
fractal: Complex Geometric Shape That Can Be Split into Parts, Each of Which is a Reduced-scale Copy of the Whole
graph: Representation of Data Using Nodes and Edges
intercept: Point Where a Line Crosses an Axis
manifold: Topological Space That Locally Resembles Euclidean Space
matrix: Array of Numbers, Symbols, or Expressions Arranged in Rows and Columns
mdas: Multiplication and Division (left to right), Addition and Subtraction (left to right)
ncert: National Council of Educational Research and Training
nilpotent: Element Whose Powers Are All Zero
pemdas: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication and Division (left to right), Addition and Subtraction (left to right)
polyhedron: Solid in Three Dimensions with Flat Polygonal Faces, Straight Edges, and Sharp Corners
prime: Number Greater Than One That Cannot Be Formed by Multiplying Two Smaller Natural Numbers
quartile: Values that Divide a Data Set into Four Equal Parts
range: Difference Between the Highest and Lowest Values in a Data Set
rational: Number that Can Be Expressed as the Quotient or Fraction p/q of Two Integers, Where p is the Numerator and q is the Denominator
root: Value That, When Multiplied by Itself, Gives the Original Number
scalar: Single Real Number Used to Scale a Vector
statistics: Branch of Mathematics Dealing with the Collection, Analysis, Interpretation, Presentation, and Organization of Data
tangent: Ratio of the Opposite to the Adjacent Side in a Right Triangle
theorem: Statement That Has Been Proven on the Basis of Previously Established Statements
trigonometry: Branch of Mathematics Dealing with Relations of the Angles of Triangles to the Sides and Angles
vertex: Point Where Two or More Lines Meet
volume: Amount of Space Occupied by an Object
x-axis: Horizontal Axis in a Cartesian Coordinate System
y-axis: Vertical Axis in a Cartesian Coordinate System
zero: No Quantity or Number; the Absence or Lack of Something
amoled: Active Matrix Organic Light Emitting Diode
edge: Enhanced Data Rates for GSM Evolution
emoji: Small Digital Image or Icon Used to Express an Idea or Emotion
hotspot: Area with Access to the Internet
tethering: Using a Mobile Device as a Modem
saarc: South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation
bipac: Business and Industry Political Action Committee
gatt: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade
islam: Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant
oecd: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
pco: President's Commission on the Status of Women
unicef: United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund
usaid: United States Agency for International Development
youthquake: Significant Cultural, Political, or Social Change Arising from the Actions or Influence of Young People
zealot: Person Who is Fanatical and Uncompromising in Pursuit of Religious, Political, or Other Ideals
bolshevik: Member of the Majority Faction of the Russian Social Democratic Party
brexit: British Exit from the European Union
bureaucracy: Administrative System, Especially a Government, that Uses a Large Number of Officials
capitalism: Economic and Political System in Which a Country's Trade and Industry are Controlled by Private Owners for Profit
citizen: Member of a State or Nation, Especially One with Civil Rights and Duties
communism: Social and Economic Ideology Advocating for the Collective Ownership and Control of Production and Distribution
conservative: Political Ideology or Ethos That Favors Tradition and Limited Government
democracy: System of Government in Which Power is Held by the People, Either Directly or Through Elected Representatives
divisiveness: Tendency to Cause Disagreement or Hostility Between People
egalitarian: Believing in or Advocating for the Principle of Equal Rights and Opportunities for All
fascism: Authoritarian and Nationalistic Right-Wing System of Government and Social Organization
federalism: Federal Principle or System of Government
globalization: Process of Interaction and Integration Among People, Companies, and Governments from Different Nations
ideology: System of Ideas and Ideals, Especially One That Forms the Basis of Economic or Political Theory and Policy
imperialism: Policy or Ideology of Extending a Country's Power and Influence Through Colonization or Military Force
jingoism: Extreme Patriotism, Especially in the Form of Aggressive or Warlike Foreign Policy
kleptocracy: Government by Those Who Seek Chiefly Status and Personal Gain at the Expense of the Governed
lobbyist: Person Who Takes Part in an Organized Attempt to Influence Legislators
marxism: Political and Economic Theories of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels
nepotism: Practice Among Those with Power or Influence of Favoring Relatives or Friends, Especially by Giving Them Jobs
oligarchy: Small Group of People Having Control of a Country, Organization, or Institution
populism: Political Approach That Strives to Appeal to Ordinary People Who Feel That Their Concerns are Disregarded by Established Elites
quorum: Minimum Number of Members Present for a Meeting to Be Valid
republic: State in Which Supreme Power is Held by the People and Their Elected Representatives
socialism: Political and Economic Theory Advocating for Ownership and Control of the Means of Production and Distribution by the Community as a Whole
totalitarianism: System of Government That is Centralized and Dictatorial and Requires Complete Subservience to the State
veto: Right to Reject a Decision or Proposal Made by a Law-Making Body
whistleblower: Person Who Informs on a Person or Organization Engaged in an Illicit Activity
xenophobia: Dislike of or Prejudice Against People from Other Countries
isotope: Atoms of the Same Element with Different Numbers of Neutrons
sesame: Synthetic Environment for Simulation and Analysis of Molecular Evolution
naacp: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People
peta: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
streamer: Person Who Broadcasts Content on Online Platforms
influencer: Person Who Has the Power to Influence Others Due to Their Authority, Knowledge, Position, or Relationship
troll: Person Who Deliberately Provokes Others Online
memes: Cultural Ideas, Behaviors, or Styles That Spread from Person to Person Within a Culture
selfie: Self-Portrait Photograph Taken with a Smartphone or Camera
hashtag: Word or Phrase Preceded by the Pound Sign (#), Used on Social Media to Identify Messages on a Specific Topic
emoji: Digital Representation of a Person, Place, Thing, or Idea Expressed through Various Characters
bias: Voltage or Current Applied to Establish Operating Conditions
csma/cd: Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection
nanotechnology: Manipulation of Matter at the Nanoscale
word: Number of Bits Processed at a Time by a Computer's CPU
ascii: American Standard Code for Information Interchange
unicode: Standard for Encoding, Representing, and Handling Text
oecd: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
laissez-faire: Policy of Minimal Government Intervention in Economic Affairs
oligopoly: Market Dominated by a Small Number of Large Sellers
cartel: Group of Independent Producers that Regulate Production, Pricing, and Marketing
demand: Quantity of a Good or Service Consumers Are Willing to Buy at a Given Price
supply: Quantity of a Good or Service Producers Are Willing to Offer at a Given Price
equilibrium: Point Where Supply and Demand Intersect
elasticity: Sensitivity of Quantity Demanded or Supplied to Changes in Price or Income
subsidy: Financial Support from the Government to Encourage Production or Consumption
quota: Limit on the Quantity of a Good That Can Be Imported
inflation: Rise in the General Price Level of Goods and Services in an Economy
deflation: Decrease in the General Price Level of Goods and Services in an Economy
stagflation: Simultaneous High Inflation and High Unemployment
recession: Period of Decline in Economic Activity, Typically Lasting for a Few Months
fiscal policy: Government's Use of Taxation and Spending to Influence the Economy
monetary policy: Central Bank's Control of the Money Supply and Interest Rates
interest rate: Cost of Borrowing Money or Return on Investment
exchange rate: Value of One Currency in Terms of Another
budget deficit: When a Government Spends More Money than It Collects in Taxes
budget surplus: When a Government Collects More Money in Taxes than It Spends
national debt: Total Amount of Money That a Government Owes to Its Creditors
crowding out: Reduction in Private Sector Investment Due to Increased Government Borrowing
opportunity cost: Value of the Next Best Alternative that Must Be Forgone
comparative advantage: Ability to Produce a Good or Service at a Lower Opportunity Cost than Other Producers
invisible hand: Concept in Economics Describing Self-Regulating Nature of the Market
market economy: Economic System Where Decisions on Production and Consumption Are Based on Supply and Demand
command economy: Economic System Where Decisions on Production and Consumption Are Centrally Planned by the Government
mixed economy: Combination of Market and Command Economic Systems
labor market: Place Where Workers and Employers Interact
capital market: Financial Market for Buying and Selling Long-Term Debt or Equity Securities
commodity market: Market for Trading in Primary Economic Sector Goods
perfect competition: Market Structure with Many Small Firms and Identical Products
monopolistic competition: Market Structure with Many Firms Selling Differentiated Products
oligopoly: Market Structure Dominated by a Small Number of Large Firms
monopoly: Market Structure with a Single Seller Dominating the Market
productivity: Efficiency of Production, Measured as Output Per Unit of Input
efficiency: Achieving Maximum Output with Minimum Input
utility: Satisfaction or Pleasure Derived from Consuming a Good or Service
marginal cost: Additional Cost Incurred by Producing One More Unit of a Good or Service
marginal revenue: Additional Revenue Generated by Selling One More Unit of a Good or Service
labor force: Total Number of Workers, Including Employed and Unemployed
human capital: Skills, Knowledge, and Experience Possessed by an Individual or Population
capitalism: Economic System Where the Means of Production Are Privately Owned
socialism: Economic System Where the Means of Production Are Owned or Regulated by the Community as a Whole
communism: Economic System Where All Property Is Publicly Owned, and Each Person Works and Is Paid According to Their Abilities and Needs
profit: Financial Gain from a Business Operation
interest: Charge for the Use of Borrowed Money
rent: Payment for the Use of Property or Land
entrepreneur: Individual Who Organizes and Operates a Business, Taking on Financial Risks
macroeconomics: Study of the Economy as a Whole
microeconomics: Study of Individual Markets and Industries
supply and demand: Basic Economic Model Describing the Relationship Between Buyers and Sellers
elasticity of demand: Sensitivity of Quantity Demanded to Changes in Price
utility maximization: Consumer's Goal of Getting the Highest Possible Satisfaction from Goods and Services
profit maximization: Firm's Goal of Earning the Highest Possible Profit
market failure: Situation Where the Allocation of Goods and Services Is Not Efficient
public goods: Goods and Services Provided by the Government for the Benefit of All Citizens
externalities: Unintended Side Effects of Economic Activities Affecting Third Parties
perfect information: Assumption in Economics that All Market Participants Have Full Knowledge
game theory: Study of Mathematical Models of Strategic Interaction Between Rational Decision-Makers
absolute advantage: Ability to Produce More of a Good or Service Than Competitors Using the Same Amount of Resources
devaluation: Reduction in the Value of a Currency Relative to Other Currencies
appreciation: Increase in the Value of a Currency Relative to Other Currencies
balance of trade: Difference Between the Value of a Country's Exports and Imports
trade deficit: When a Country Imports More Goods and Services than It Exports
trade surplus: When a Country Exports More Goods and Services than It Imports
barter: Exchange of Goods and Services Without Using Money
fiat money: Currency that Has No Intrinsic Value and Is Not Backed by a Physical Commodity
fractional reserve banking: Banking System Where Only a Fraction of Bank Deposits Is Backed by Actual Cash
central bank: Institution Responsible for Issuing a Country's Currency, Regulating Its Money Supply, and Controlling Interest Rates
moral hazard: Risk That One Party Can Take Advantage of Knowing More Than the Other Party in a Transaction
liquidity: Ease with Which an Asset Can Be Converted into Cash
quantitative easing: Monetary Policy Tool Used by Central Banks to Increase Money Supply
subprime mortgage: A Type of Mortgage Loan Granted to Individuals with Poor Credit Histories
sovereign debt: Debt Issued by a National Government in a Foreign Currency
hedge fund: Investment Fund That Pools Capital from Accredited Individuals or Institutional Investors
derivatives: Financial Contracts Whose Value Is Derived from the Performance of an Underlying Asset
black swan: Unpredictable or Rare Events with Severe Consequences
laffer curve: Concept Illustrating the Relationship Between Tax Rates and Tax Revenue
stagflation: Economic Condition with High Inflation and High Unemployment
tragedy of the commons: Concept Describing the Overuse or Depletion of a Shared Resource
paradox of thrift: Situation Where Increased Saving by Individuals Can Lead to a Decrease in Overall Spending and Economic Growth
opportunity cost: The Value of the Next Best Alternative that Must Be Forgone
diminishing marginal utility: Concept That the Additional Satisfaction Gained from Consuming One More Unit of a Good or Service Decreases as Consumption Increases
free rider problem: Situation Where Individuals Benefit from a Public Good Without Paying for It
economic rent: Payment to a Factor of Production in Excess of What Is Required to Keep It in Its Current Use
rational expectations: Economic Theory Assuming That Individuals Make Decisions Based on Rational Behavior and Perfect Information
rent-seeking: Act of Obtaining Special Treatment or Privileges from the Government to Enhance Personal Wealth
creative destruction: Process Where New Technologies and Industries Replace Outdated Ones
green economy: Economic System Focused on Environmental Sustainability
heterodox economics: Economic Theories and Approaches That Differ from Mainstream or Orthodox Economics
supply-side economics: Economic Theory Emphasizing Tax Cuts and Deregulation to Stimulate Economic Growth
demand-side economics: Economic Theory Emphasizing Government Spending and Tax Policies to Stimulate Demand
fiat currency: Currency Declared by a Government to Be Legal Tender, Despite Having No Intrinsic Value
mixed economy: Economic System Combining Elements of Market and Command Economies
shadow banking: Financial Activities Conducted Outside of Traditional Banking Institutions
hedging: Financial Strategy to Reduce or Offset Risk
invisible hand: Concept Describing the Self-Regulating Nature of the Market
regressive tax: Tax That Takes a Larger Percentage from Low-Income Earners Than from High-Income Earners
progressive tax: Tax That Takes a Larger Percentage from High-Income Earners Than from Low-Income Earners
regulation: Government Rules or Laws Aimed at Controlling Economic Activities
deregulation: Removal or Relaxation of Government Regulations on an Industry
structural unemployment: Unemployment Resulting from Changes in the Structure of the Economy
frictional unemployment: Temporary Unemployment Experienced by Individuals Moving Between Jobs
cyclical unemployment: Unemployment Resulting from Economic Contractions or Downturns
seasonal unemployment: Unemployment Resulting from Changes in the Seasons or Weather
wealth inequality: Unequal Distribution of Assets Among Individuals or Populations
income inequality: Unequal Distribution of Income Among Individuals or Populations
leverage: Use of Various Financial Instruments or Borrowed Capital to Increase the Potential Return of an Investment
price elasticity of demand: Sensitivity of Quantity Demanded to Changes in Price
principal-agent problem: Situation Where One Party (the Agent) Acts on Behalf of Another Party (the Principal) but May Have Different Interests
asymmetric information: Situation Where One Party in a Transaction Has More or Better Information Than the Other Party
deficit spending: Government Spending Exceeding Revenue, Resulting in a Budget Deficit
austerity: Economic Policy of Reducing Government Spending and Increasing Taxes to Control Debt
automatic stabilizer: Economic Policies or Programs Designed to Counteract Economic Fluctuations Without Explicit Government Intervention
complementary goods: Goods That Are Typically Used Together, So the Increase in Demand for One Leads to an Increase in Demand for the Other
substitute goods: Goods That Can Be Used in Place of Each Other, So the Increase in Demand for One Leads to a Decrease in Demand for the Other
nasdaq: National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations
bear market: A market characterized by declining prices.
bull market: A market characterized by rising prices.
stock: A share in the ownership of a company, representing a claim on part of the company's assets and earnings.
dividend: A payment made by a corporation to its shareholders, usually in the form of cash or additional shares.
blue chip stocks: Shares in large, well-established companies with a history of stable performance.
ipo: Initial Public Offering - the first sale of stock by a private company to the public.
market capitalization: The total value of a company's outstanding shares of stock, calculated by multiplying the share price by the number of shares.
stock exchange: A marketplace where buyers and sellers trade stocks.
stockbroker: A licensed professional who buys and sells stocks on behalf of clients.
index: A measurement of the value of a section of the stock market.
volatility: A statistical measure of the dispersion of returns for a given security or market index.
options: Financial contracts that give the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an asset at a specific price before a certain date.
bonds: A fixed-income security that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower, typically a corporation or government.
mutual fund: An investment vehicle made up of a pool of funds collected from many investors for the purpose of investing in securities.
hedge fund: An investment fund that pools capital from accredited individuals or institutional investors and invests in a variety of assets.
day trading: The practice of buying and selling financial instruments within the same trading day.
market order: An order to buy or sell a security immediately at the best available price.
limit order: An order to buy or sell a security at a specific price or better.
short selling: The sale of a security that is not owned by the seller or that the seller has borrowed.
margin: Borrowed money used to purchase securities.
bullish: An optimistic view on the market or a particular asset.
bearish: A pessimistic view on the market or a particular asset.
asset: Anything of value owned by an individual, corporation, or country.
liability: A company's financial debts or obligations.
liquidity: The ability to convert an asset into cash quickly without affecting its price.
equity: Ownership interest in a corporation in the form of common stock or preferred stock.
portfolio: A collection of financial investments, like stocks, bonds, and cash equivalents, as well as their mutual, exchange-traded, and closed fund counterparts.
capital gains: Profit made from the sale of an investment.
diversification: A risk management strategy that mixes a wide variety of investments within a portfolio.
earnings per share (EPS): A company's profit divided by its number of outstanding shares.
price-to-earnings ratio (P/E): The ratio for valuing a company that measures its current share price relative to its per-share earnings.
bid: The price a buyer is willing to pay for a security.
ask: The price a seller is willing to sell a security for.
brokerage account: An account that allows an investor to buy and sell securities.
capital market: A financial market in which long-term debt or equity-backed securities are bought and sold.
bond: A fixed-income security that represents a loan made by an investor to a borrower, typically a corporation or government.
bond rating: An evaluation of the credit quality of a corporate or government bond.
book value: The value of a security or asset on the books of the company.
broker: An individual or firm that charges a fee or commission for executing buy or sell orders submitted by an investor.
buy limit order: An order to purchase a security at or below a specified price.
buy stop order: An order to buy a security at a price above the current market price.
call option: A financial contract that gives the holder the right, but not the obligation, to buy an asset at a predetermined price within a specified timeframe.
circuit breaker: A temporary halt in trading to curb panic-selling or prevent market collapse.
closing price: The final trading price of a security at the end of the trading session.
commodities: Physical goods such as gold, oil, and agricultural products traded on exchanges.
common stock: A type of security that represents ownership in a corporation and entitles the holder to voting rights.
compounding: The process in which an investment earns interest not only on the principal amount but also on the accumulated interest.
convertible bond: A bond that can be converted into a predetermined amount of the issuer's equity.
correction: A reverse movement, usually negative, in the price of a stock or a financial market.
coupon rate: The annual interest rate paid on a bond, expressed as a percentage of the face value.
currency: A system of money in common use, typically for a nation.
day trader: An individual who engages in the practice of buying and selling financial instruments within the same trading day.
debit spread: A spread strategy where an investor purchases an option with a higher premium and sells an option with a lower premium.
deflation: A decrease in the general price level of goods and services.
derivative: A financial instrument whose value is derived from the value of an underlying asset.
dilution: A reduction in the ownership percentage of a share of stock caused by the issuance of new shares.
dividend yield: A financial ratio that shows how much a company pays out in dividends each year relative to its share price.
dow jones industrial average (djia): An index that measures the performance of 30 large, publicly-owned companies trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
economics: The branch of knowledge concerned with the production, consumption, and transfer of wealth.
etf: Exchange-Traded Fund - a type of investment fund and exchange-traded product.
euro: The official currency of the Eurozone.
ex-dividend date: The first day of trading when the seller, rather than the buyer, is entitled to the most recent dividend payment.
exchange: A marketplace where securities, commodities, derivatives, and other financial instruments are traded.
exchange rate: The rate at which one currency can be exchanged for another.
federal reserve: The central banking system of the United States.
futures contract: A financial contract obligating the buyer to purchase, or the seller to sell, a particular asset or financial instrument at a predetermined future date and price.
fundamental analysis: A method of evaluating a security's intrinsic value by examining related economic, financial, and other qualitative and quantitative factors.
gamma: A measure of how much an option's delta is expected to change for a one-point change in the price of the underlying asset.
golden cross: A bullish technical indicator that occurs when the short-term moving average of an asset crosses above its long-term moving average.
growth stock: A stock that is expected to grow at an above-average rate compared to other companies.
hedge: An investment position intended to offset potential losses or gains that may be incurred by a companion investment.
high-frequency trading (hft): A type of algorithmic trading characterized by high speeds, high turnover rates, and high order-to-trade ratios.
inflation: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, and subsequently purchasing power is falling.
initial public offering (ipo): The first sale of stock by a private company to the public.
insider trading: The buying or selling of a security by someone who has access to material, nonpublic information about the security.
interest rate: The amount charged by a lender to a borrower for the use of assets, expressed as a percentage of the principal.
inverse etf: An exchange-traded fund that aims to deliver returns in the opposite direction of its benchmark index.
investment: The act of allocating resources, usually money, with the expectation of generating an income or profit.
junk bond: A high-yield or non-investment grade bond.
kelly criterion: A mathematical formula for determining the optimal size of a series of bets.
leverage: The use of various financial instruments or borrowed capital to increase the potential return of an investment.
libor: London Interbank Offered Rate - the benchmark interest rate at which major global banks lend to one another in the international interbank market.
long position: An investment position that benefits from an increase in the price of the underlying asset.
maintenance margin: The minimum amount of equity that must be maintained in a margin account.
margin call: A demand from a broker that an investor deposit additional money or securities to cover possible losses.
market risk: The possibility for an investor to experience losses due to factors that affect the overall performance of the financial markets.
moving average: A statistical calculation used to analyze data points by creating a series of averages of different subsets of the full data set.
nasdaq: National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations - an American stock exchange.
net asset value (nav): The total value of a mutual fund's or ETF's assets minus liabilities, divided by the number of shares outstanding.
nominal value: The face value of a security stated by the issuer.
option: A financial derivative that represents a contract sold by one party to another.
over-the-counter (otc): Trading of financial instruments directly between two parties, without a central exchange or broker.
penny stock: A common stock valued at less than one dollar.
portfolio: A collection of financial investments, like stocks, bonds, and cash equivalents.
preferred stock: A type of stock that has a higher claim on assets and earnings than common stock.
price-earnings ratio (p/e ratio): A valuation ratio calculated by dividing the market price per share by the earnings per share.
primary market: The market where new securities are issued and sold to investors for the first time.
put option: A financial contract giving the owner the right, but not the obligation, to sell a specified amount of an underlying security at a specified price within a specified time.
quantitative easing: A monetary policy in which a central bank purchases government securities or other securities from the market to lower interest rates and increase the money supply.
gnp: Gross National Product - the total value of all goods and services produced by a country's residents within a specific time period, plus the income earned by its residents abroad, minus the income earned by foreign residents within the country.
nnp: Net National Product - GNP minus depreciation.
gdp: Gross Domestic Product - the total value of all goods and services produced within a country's borders within a specific time period.
ndp: Net Domestic Product - GDP minus depreciation.
nfi: Net Foreign Investment - the difference between a country's external assets and liabilities.
mp: Market Price - the price at which a product or service is offered in the market.
fc: Fixed Cost - costs that do not vary with the level of production or output.
int: Interest - a fee paid by a borrower to the lender for the use of money.
savi: Savings - the portion of income not spent on consumption.
narega: National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (NREGA) - a social security measure that aims to guarantee the 'right to work' and ensure livelihood security for rural households.
manrega: Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) - a social security measure that guarantees the right to work for every adult member of a rural household.
mrp: Maximum Retail Price - the highest price at which a product can legally be sold to consumers.
arf: Automatic Fire Detection and Alarm Systems
safed: Society for Fire Protection Engineers Development
niosh: National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
nabp: National Association of Boards of Pharmacy
nccmerp: National Coordinating Council for Medication Error Reporting and Prevention
ibrd: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
fastag: Fast, Advanced, and Secure Toll Collection
police: Polite Obedient Loyal Intelligent Courageous and Efficient
cricket: A bat-and-ball game played between two teams of eleven players each on a circular field.
test: A traditional format of cricket that spans up to five days, considered the highest standard.
odi: One Day International, a limited-overs cricket format with each team facing a set number of overs.
t20: Twenty20, a short format of cricket with each team allowed to bat and bowl for a maximum of 20 overs.
innings: A unit of play in which one team bats and the other bowls, usually consisting of overs or a set number of deliveries.
wicket: A set of three stumps and two bails at each end of the cricket pitch; also refers to the dismissal of a batsman.
boundary: The line or marker that marks the outer edge of the playing field; hitting the ball beyond it scores four or six runs.
over: A set of six consecutive deliveries bowled by a bowler from one end of the pitch.
run: The basic unit of scoring in cricket, achieved by the batsmen running between the wickets after a valid shot.
six: A shot that clears the boundary without bouncing, resulting in six runs.
four: A shot that reaches the boundary after bouncing, resulting in four runs.
duck: A batsman getting out without scoring any runs.
lbw: Leg Before Wicket, a mode of dismissal where the batsman is declared out if the ball hits their leg before the bat.
century: Scoring 100 runs by an individual batsman in an inning.
hat-trick: A bowler taking three wickets on three consecutive deliveries.
no-ball: An illegal delivery by the bowler, resulting in an extra run for the batting side.
wide: A delivery that is too wide for the batsman to play, resulting in an extra run for the batting side.
umpire: The match official responsible for making decisions on the field, including judging whether a batsman is out.
dismissal: The act of putting a batsman out, ending their innings.
man-of-the-match: A player judged as the best performer in a cricket match.
football: A team sport played between two teams of eleven players each, aiming to score goals by getting a ball into the opposing team's goal.
pitch: The playing field or ground where football matches are conducted.
goal: A structure with a net into which the ball must be kicked to score points.
penalty: A kick awarded to the opposing team if a defensive player commits a foul in their penalty area.
free-kick: A kick awarded to a team following a foul, where the opposing team must maintain a certain distance.
corner-kick: A kick awarded to the attacking team when the ball goes out of play over the goal line, taken from the corner flag.
offside: A rule that a player is in an offside position if they are nearer to the opponent's goal than both the ball and the second-to-last defender.
dribble: The skillful control and manipulation of the ball by a player using their feet.
tackle: An attempt by a defensive player to take the ball away from an opponent.
header: A play in which a player strikes the ball with their head.
nutmeg: Passing the ball through an opponent's legs and retrieving it on the other side.
hat-trick: A player scoring three goals in a single game.
draw: A result where neither team wins or loses; the match ends in a tie.
extra-time: Additional playing time added to a match if the score is tied at the end of regular time.
penalty-shootout: A method of determining the winner in a tied match by a series of penalty kicks.
foul: A rule violation committed by a player, resulting in a free-kick or penalty for the opposing team.
yellow-card: A caution issued by the referee to a player as a warning for a rule infringement.
red-card: A player being sent off the field for a serious foul or misconduct.
manager: The head coach or manager responsible for the team's strategy and player selection.
captain: A designated team leader who usually wears an armband and has specific on-field responsibilities.
referee: The match official responsible for enforcing the rules and making decisions during the game.
stadium: A large sports venue with seating for spectators, where football matches are held.
World Cup: The FIFA World Cup, an international football competition held every four years featuring national teams from around the world.
